title: High Security, Ban On Face Paint & Weird Behaviour: 5 Things That Happened At Joker Screenings
text:
Can a movie be a cause for violence? Joker’s depiction of violence is currently the topic of debate. The film glorifies violence and encourages people to sympathise with a villainous character, some people say.

Even before the release of Joker, people feared that the movie might be a cause of mass shootings. Why? Because a similar incident had happened in the past!

cbsnews3

On July 20, 2012, a mass shooting happened inside the Century 16 movie theater in Aurora, Colorado, during the midnight screening of The Dark Knight Rises, a Batman film. The accused, James Eagan Holmes, who is now serving 12 life sentences showed up dressed in tactical clothing, set of tear gas grenades and shot into the audiences. 12 people were killed and several others were injured. According to the officials, James Eagan Holmes had dyed his hair red and called himself The Joker.

Can the history repeat itself? Many people fear it can. Hence, high security has been deployed at theatres, particularly in the US.

Here are five things that have happened at Joker screenings in the recent past that left people even more terrified that the movie.

#1 A man who cheered and applauded whenever Joker killed a character in the movie was kicked out of the theatre.

A man who came to watch Joker at a theatre near Times Square was reportedly spitting at the patrons and also cheering loudly and applauding when characters would die on the screen. He was soon kicked out of the theatre.

#2 Costumes, masks and face paint were banned during screenings.

Twitter

Many cinema halls including the Baxter Avenue Theatres and Landmark Theatre chain among others, had banned the use of costumes, masks and face paint during the screening of Joker. A sign outside the Louisville theatre read "due to recent warnings," the theatre "will not be allowing any costumes into the theater during our run of 'The Joker.' No costumes, face paint or masks allowed at any time, you will be asked to leave. We apologize for any inconvenience.”

#3 Audiences at a California theatre fled after a suspicious male entered the theatre with a backpack. He was then arrested.

At a movie theatre in Long Beach, California, people self-evacuated themselves from the movie theatre after a suspicious man wearing a backpack was staring at everyone near the exit gates. “The suspect was detained and was not found in possession of any weapons, however he was taken into custody for an unrelated outstanding warrant.”

#4 In Chicago, Two men were taken into custody after they smoked, blew smoke in other cinema-goer’s faces and talked loudly during the screening of Joker.

At AMC River East 21 movie theater in Streeterville, police were called after two men were smoking and talking loudly during the screening of the movie. They were then taken away in handcuffs.

#5 Joker screenings at Los Angeles were cancelled after credible threat.

At a movie theatre in Huntington Beach, California, Joker screening was cancelled after a “credible” threat was reported to the police. "The police department deemed the threat was credible enough to provide a uniformed presence at the theater," the statement by Huntington Beach Police Department read. The police, however, didn’t reveal the nature of the threat.
